'''Tropius''' ([[List of Japanese Pokémon names|Japanese]]: '''トロピウス''' ''Tropius'') is a dual-type {{2t|Grass|Flying}} {{OBP|Pokémon|species}} introduced in [[Generation III]].

It is not known to [[Evolution|evolve]] into or from any other Pokémon.

==Biology==
Tropius is a large {{wp|sauropod}}-like Pokémon with a brown body wrapped in green leaves on its chest and head. It possesses large, broad green leaves on its back, which it uses for flight and for sugar production via photosynthesis. Despite being very big and bulky, it is surprisingly maneuverable in the air. It has a long neck, which it uses for reaching treetops to gorge on its most favored fruit. Since it ate only this kind of fruit continuously, the fruit began to grow around its neck. These yellow, banana-like fruits can be picked and consumed by other Pokémon or humans, and grow twice a year because of the rapid production of sugar in Tropius's leaves. Its feet have toenails the same color as its fruit. 

In warm areas, there are ranches that raise Tropius. In [[Alola]], its fruit is especially sweet compared to those of other regions. It lives in {{DL|List of Pokémon by habitat|Forest Pokémon|tropical jungles}}.

==In the anime==
[[File:Camomile Island Tropius.png|left|thumb|220px|Tropius in the {{pkmn|anime}}]]
===Major appearances===
A Tropius appeared in ''[[AG127|From Brags to Riches]]''. A Trainer named [[Dominick]] used the Fruit Pokémon and a {{p|Swalot}} in his battle against [[Ash's Corphish]] and {{AP|Torkoal}}. Tropius and Torkoal knocked each other out when their {{m|Solar Beam}} and {{m|Overheat}} attacks connected and created an explosion.

A wild Tropius challenged [[Ash's Grovyle]] in ''[[AG161|Odd Pokémon Out]]'' when it and Grovyle were competitors for the love of [[Nurse Joy]]'s {{p|Meganium}}.

===Minor appearances===
Tropius debuted in ''[[M06|Jirachi: Wish Maker]]'', where it was among those fleeing from the {{OBP|Groudon|M06}} that was trying to snatch all the Pokémon.

A {{pkmn|Trainer}}'s Tropius appeared in ''[[AG125|Like a Meowth to a Flame]]''.

A Tropius appeared in the opening sequences of ''[[M07|Destiny Deoxys]]'' and ''[[M13|Zoroark: Master of Illusions]]''.

A Tropius participated in the [[Rota]] competition in ''[[M08|Lucario and the Mystery of Mew]]'', battling [[Kidd Summers]]'s {{p|Weavile}}. Also, another appeared in the opening sequence of the movie.

A Tropius appeared in ''[[M10|The Rise of Darkrai]]'', where it was one of the Pokémon {{OBP|Darkrai|M10}} hit with a {{m|Dark Void}}.

===In the Pokémon Adventures manga===
{{main|Troppy}}
{{adv|Sapphire}} owns a Tropius named [[Troppy]] given to her by [[Professor Birch|her father]] for flying purposes. He first appeared in ''[[PS213|Bubble Bubble Toil and Azumarill II]]''.

A Tropius appeared in ''[[PS217|Mind-Boggling with Medicham]]''.

A Trainer's Tropius appeared in ''[[PS418|Deprogramming Porygon-Z]]''.

{{OBP|Enta|CBF}} has a Tropius which helped him reach the top of the Battle Pyramid.

==Trivia==
* Tropius is exactly the same size as another {{type|Grass}} Pokémon, {{p|Venusaur}}. Both have a height of 6'7" (2.0 m) and a weight of 220.5&nbsp;lbs. (100.0&nbsp;kg).
* Tropius was the first Pokémon to be distributed in a {{ball|Cherish}}, with the {{DL|List of local Japanese event Pokémon distributions in Generation IV|Shokotan Tropius}} distribution.
* Tropius shares its category with {{p|Bounsweet}}, {{p|Steenee}} and {{p|Tsareena}}. They are all known as the Fruit Pokémon.

===Origin===
Tropius resembles a generic {{wp|sauropoda|sauropod}} (a long-necked, herbivorous dinosaur) combined with a {{wp|banana}} plant.

====Name origin====
Tropius is a combination of ''tropical'' and ''saurus'' (Greek for ''lizard''). It may also be a pun of ''tropism'': {{wp|phototropism}} is when plants move to catch more sunlight, and if a plant is not planted upright, the roots will use {{wp|gravitropism}} to grow towards gravity and find water.
